Books to consider.title: terraforming novels
Books to consider.notes: "2312" by Kim Stanley Robinson (2012): Set in a future where humanity has colonized the solar system, this novel explores a broad range of terraforming efforts across various celestial bodies.

Books to consider.title: Arkady Martine — A Desolation Called Peace
curriculum leading up to a reread of Terra Ignota
Books to consider.notes: Voltaire's "Candide": Palmer has cited Voltaire's work as a direct influence. "Candide," with its satirical take on philosophy and society, especially the critique of optimism, resonates strongly with the themes in "Terra Ignota."

Books to consider.title: Penrose: the Road to Reality
Books to consider.notes: Seems to be doing something similar to Carroll's Biggest Ideas series, but more complete and in one volume

Books to consider.title: A Few Notes on the Culture
Bess recos
Books to consider.notes: Plato's Apology and Euthyphro: Both are relatively short, you get introduced to Socrates, and Euthyphro especially is an example of dialectic that Plato loves so much.

Books to consider.title: The notebook: a history of thinking on paper
The Japanese one by the lady about when she was in school
Ernaux — The Years
Books to consider.notes: ChatGPT makes this sound like it’ll resonate with my experience; Celine also recommends

Books to consider.title: Milner — A Life of One's Own
Eggers — A Heartbreaking Work of Staggering Genius
Sevareid: Not So Wild a Dream
Making It up as You Go Along: Notes From a Bass Impostor
The history of rock in 500 songs
Things Become Other Things: A Walking Memoir
Taishou era recos
Books to consider.notes: Certainly! Here’s a brief version of the recommendations for your reading list:

Books to consider.title: Egan — Diaspora
Books to consider.notes: Diaspora comes recommended for Permutation City fans

Books to consider.title: Further Egan
Books to consider.notes: Axiomatic has high “punches packed per page”

Books to consider.title: omelas, the ones who stay and fight, why don't we just kill
In the court of king crimson
Celine recos
Books to consider.notes: The Uncontrollability of the World feels like a better version of a Byung-Chul Han book.3 By this, I mean: short; contains a sweeping theory about What’s Wrong With Modernity (but the diagnosis is profoundly humanistic, not reactionary and revanchist); feels like a “serious” and “intellectual” read, but is easily assimilated into your existing worldview. If you read and liked James C. Scott’s Seeing Like a State or Donella Meadows’s Thinking in Systems, this book is very complementary!

Books to consider.title: Manhunt: The 12-Day Chase for Lincoln's Killer
Resolving conflict
Books to consider.notes: Check out Resolving Conflict, from the Waking Up app:

Books to consider.title: The Palace of Eternity
Books to consider.notes: Bookpilled — A-tier, short, does a lot with the time it takes

Books to consider.title: A Case of Conscience
Books to consider.notes: Bookpilled says it's the best religious sf, and way better than Leibowitz

Books to consider.title: Children follow-up:  The Gardener and the Carpenter (print reread)
Philosophical follow-up: Four Thousand Weeks (print reread)
Philosophical follow-up: How to Live Weeks (print reread)
The Righteous Mind by Jonathan Haidt
Books to consider.notes: Reread to refresh your grasp on moral intuitions. Focus on the six moral foundations and the idea that reasoning follows intuition. Use this as a lens for all the others.

Books to consider.title: Notes Toward the Definition of Culture by T.S. Eliot
Books to consider.notes: Culture as fragile inheritance. A dense, formal argument for tradition, religion, and class continuity as the substrate of shared life. Read meditatively.

Books to consider.title: Candide by Voltaire
Books to consider.notes: Satirical and brutal; demolishes blind optimism. Ends in pragmatic quietism (“cultivate our garden”). Pairs well with Camus on rebellion and absurdity.

Books to consider.title: Songs of Innocence and of Experience by William Blake
Books to consider.notes: Read aloud, explore the engravings. Tracks the tension between naïve purity and hardened insight. “Without contraries is no progression.”

Books to consider.title: The Need for Roots by Simone Weil
Books to consider.notes: Demanding and incandescent. Argues that people need obligations more than rights, and spiritual rootedness to stay whole. Read slowly and take notes.

Books to consider.title: Gilead by Marilynne Robinson
Books to consider.notes: Gentle, luminous novel in the form of a minister’s letter to his son. Graceful reflection on memory, forgiveness, and the holiness of ordinary life.

Books to consider.title: Paul Halpern — The Allure of the Multiverse
Chiara Marletto — The Science of Can and Can’t
David Deutsch — The Fabric of Reality
Clarke — Jonathan Strange & Mr Norrell
Books to consider.notes: Regency-era magicians; lush period detail & footnoted world-building that echoes your O’Brian/Wolfe loves

Books to consider.title: Pavic — Dictionary of the Khazars
Books to consider.notes: Hyper-textual lexicon-novel; dreamlike 9th-century myth-weaving perfect for Detritus-style annotation

Books to consider.title: Lois McMaster Bujold — The Curse of Chalion

Japanese books to consider.notes: Playful French surrealist style; for someone meh on Murakami

Japanese books to consider.title: Land of the Lustrous (宝石の国 / Hōseki no Kuni)
Japanese books to consider.notes: Surreal fantasy about gem-like beings fending off attacks from the moon. Beautifully drawn, philosophical, occasionally melancholy.

Japanese books to consider.title: Yokohama Kaidashi Kikou (ヨコハマ買い出し紀行 / Yokohama Kaidashi Kikō)
Japanese books to consider.notes: Quiet post-apocalyptic slice-of-life. An android café owner explores a peaceful, slowly fading world. Gentle and reflective.

Japanese books to consider.title: Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind (風の谷のナウシカ / Kaze no Tani no Naushika)
Japanese books to consider.notes: A deep epic from Hayao Miyazaki. Set in a post-apocalyptic world of toxic jungles and war, but rooted in empathy and pro-nature ideals.

Japanese books to consider.title: Wombs (ウームズ / Uumuzu)
Japanese books to consider.notes: A thoughtful sci-fi about human colonists integrating their DNA with an alien species. Ethically complex but not grimdark.

Japanese books to consider.title: Read 志賀直哉『城の崎にて』 (40 pp) — quiet onsen recovery; meditative nature notes

Read 川端康成『伊豆の踊子』 (60 pp) — student’s Izu trek; brief bond with dancer troupe
Read 吉本ばなな『キッチン』 (約180 pp) — grief-softened novella; cooking & midnight kitchens nurture quiet rebirth
Read 小川洋子『博士の愛した数式』 (約200 pp) — housekeeper & amnesiac math genius forge gentle family; everyday numbers as healing spell
Read 三浦しをん『舟を編む』— lexicography crew builds a dictionary & a family
Read 宮下奈都『羊と鋼の森』— piano tuner finds his calling in Hokkaidō woods
Read 瀬尾まいこ『そして、バトンは渡された』— girl’s patchwork parents teach quiet love
Read 町田そのこ『52ヘルツのクジラたち』— misfit boy & runaway woman heal together
Read 阿部暁子『カフネ』— coffee-roads café revitalizes two drifting friends
And of course everything in my Kindle samples…
